user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1Input:
```c
static enum SHA1_RESULT
SHA1Input (struct SHA1Context *context, const unsigned char *message_array,
           unsigned length)
{
  if (! length)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
  }
  if (! context || ! message_array)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_NULL;
  }
  if (context->computed)
  {
    context->corrupted = 1;
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  if (context->corrupted)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  while (length-- && ! context->corrupted)
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++]
      = (*message_array & 0xFF);
    context->length_low += 8;
    if (context->length_low == 0)
    {
      context->length_high++;
      if (context->length_high == 0)
      {
        context->corrupted = 1;
      }
    }
    if (context->message_block_index == 64)
    {
      SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
    }
    message_array++;
  }
  return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: SHA1Input calls SHA1ProcessMessageBlock(context), which is a call to another function, not a call to SHA1Input itself. Rule 17.2 would be violated only if SHA1ProcessMessageBlock either called SHA1Input (indirect recursion) or called itself (direct recursion). There is no evidence of such recursion in the provided code, so based on the given fragment the rule is not violated.
